stories.text:
Hi HN,

I have recently came across [0] and loved the idea. I wrote a script that plays the tron game (bikes leaving a line of light behind). My script got me through to the place 486th out of 6790. I'm fascinated about this idea and would like to use the motivation momentum and I study the subject, can you suggest good books on this field?

I'd like to tackle more complex environments too where bot have to make decision between different strategies to maximize the chance to win. They had a contest [1] a few days ago where player was controlling 3 heroes to defend against spiders and other players. So I think it's not something I can solve with some fancy version of min-max?

I have run search on amazon and found a few picks, I would love to get some worthy recommendations.. * Game Hacking: Developing Autonomous Bots for Online Games by Nick Cano [2] * Game AI Pro 360: Guide to Tactics and Strategy by Steve Rabin [3] * 75 pages of results when searching for Game Theory [4]

[0] - https://www.codingame.com/multiplayer/bot-programming/line-racing [1] - https://www.codingame.com/contests/spring-challenge-2022 [2] - https://www.amazon.co.uk/Game-Hacking-Developing-Autonomous-Online/dp/1593276699/ref=sr_1_5?crid=ONIHKGSP235&keywords=bot&qid=1651565248&s=books&sprefix=bot%2Cstripbooks%2C91&sr=1-5 [3] - https://www.amazon.co.uk/Game-AI-Pro-360-Strategy/dp/0367150883/ref=sr_1_21?crid=3RPZIO8W1MJ2I&keywords=game+bot&qid=1651565682&s=books&sprefix=game+bot%2Cstripbooks%2C90&sr=1-21 [4] - https://www.amazon.co.uk/s?k=game+theory&i=stripbooks&crid=1DSAWKMLM9G7A&sprefix=game+theory%2Cstripbooks%2C106&ref=nb_sb_noss_1

stories.text:
I have some beginner<->intermediate knowledge/experience of js/html/css, and even less of python. Have only been actively (7hrs+ /wk) learning/applying this stuff for the last ~5mths, & am still (or yet to) learning many fundamentals!

However, I've been reading a LOT about Rust & Zig (& several others, but I must 'draw the line' -LOL!) on HN, and I'm very impressed/intrigued.

Would it be okay if I switched most of my focus to them, or would that be a "mistake"? It's more of a hobby all this stuff, but I do kind of want it to be a career longer-term.

I think I'll always come back to js/python & related anyway, as it's just so embedded in everything nowadays. But thinking more & more, that I would like that learning to be an offshoot/tie-in to my experiences/learnings via Rust & Zig.

Is this wrong-headed???

Thank-you.
